headline: Why Vistra, AppLovin and Oracle Are Spiraling Today
summary: With the markets taking investors on a roller coaster ride of late, three technology stocks are on the downward slope today, including Vistra (NYSE: VST), AppLovin (Nasdaq: APP) and Oracle (NYSE: ORCL). The markets have been processing strong fundamental tailwinds against worrisome economic headwinds that throw the fate of short-term interest rates into the balance. ... Why Vistra, AppLovin and Oracle Are Spiraling Today

headline: 3 Growth Companies With High Insider Ownership Expecting 46% Profit Growth
summary: In a week marked by significant volatility in the U.S. stock market, with major indices like the S&P 500 and Nasdaq poised for their biggest weekly losses since April, investors are closely watching Federal Reserve signals that may indicate an upcoming rate cut. Amid these turbulent times, growth companies with high insider ownership can present intriguing opportunities as they often reflect strong internal confidence and alignment of interests between management and shareholders.

headline: AppLovin Corporation (APP) is Attracting Investor Attention: Here is What You Should Know
summary: Recently, Zacks.com users have been paying close attention to AppLovin (APP). This makes it worthwhile to examine what the stock has in store.

headline: 3 Growth Companies With High Insider Ownership Expecting Up To 67% Earnings Growth
summary: In the midst of recent volatility, where major U.S. stock indexes have experienced significant shifts, investors are keenly observing companies that demonstrate resilience and potential for growth. Amidst this backdrop, stocks with high insider ownership often attract attention as they can signal confidence from those closest to the company’s operations and future prospects.

headline: 1 of Wall Street’s Favorite Stock on Our Buy List and 2 That Underwhelm
summary: The stocks in this article have caught Wall Street’s attention in a big way, with price targets implying returns above 20%. But investors should take these forecasts with a grain of salt because analysts typically say nice things about companies so their firms can win business in other product lines like M&A advisory.
